instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.SES.SendTemplatedEmail.SendTemplatedEmailResponse
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.SES.SendTemplatedEmail.SendTemplatedEmail
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.SES.SendTemplatedEmail.SendTemplatedEmail
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeaders Network.AWS.SES.SendTemplatedEmail.SendTemplatedEmail
instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.SES.SendTemplatedEmail.SendTemplatedEmail
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.SES.SendTemplatedEmail.SendTemplatedEmail


-- | Composes an email message and immediately queues it for sending.
--   
--   This operation is more flexible than the <tt>SendEmail</tt> API
--   operation. When you use the <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> operation, you can
--   specify the headers of the message as well as its content. This
--   flexibility is useful, for example, when you want to send a multipart
--   MIME email (such a message that contains both a text and an HTML
--   version). You can also use this operation to send messages that
--   include attachments.
--   
--   The <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> operation has the following requirements:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>You can only send email from <a>verified email addresses or
--   domains</a>. If you try to send email from an address that isn't
--   verified, the operation results in an "Email address not verified"
--   error.</li>
--   <li>If your account is still in the <a>Amazon SES sandbox</a>, you can
--   only send email to other verified addresses in your account, or to
--   addresses that are associated with the <a>Amazon SES mailbox
--   simulator</a>.</li>
--   <li>The maximum message size, including attachments, is 10 MB.</li>
--   <li>Each message has to include at least one recipient address. A
--   recipient address includes any address on the To:, CC:, or BCC:
--   lines.</li>
--   <li>If you send a single message to more than one recipient address,
--   and one of the recipient addresses isn't in a valid format (that is,
--   it's not in the format
--   <i>UserName@[SubDomain.]Domain.TopLevelDomain</i>), Amazon SES rejects
--   the entire message, even if the other addresses are valid.</li>
--   <li>Each message can include up to 50 recipient addresses across the
--   To:, CC:, or BCC: lines. If you need to send a single message to more
--   than 50 recipients, you have to split the list of recipient addresses
--   into groups of less than 50 recipients, and send separate messages to
--   each group.</li>
--   <li>Amazon SES allows you to specify 8-bit Content-Transfer-Encoding
--   for MIME message parts. However, if Amazon SES has to modify the
--   contents of your message (for example, if you use open and click
--   tracking), 8-bit content isn't preserved. For this reason, we highly
--   recommend that you encode all content that isn't 7-bit ASCII. For more
--   information, see <a>MIME Encoding</a> in the <i>Amazon SES Developer
--   Guide</i>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   Additionally, keep the following considerations in mind when using the
--   <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> operation:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Although you can customize the message headers when using the
--   <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> operation, Amazon SES will automatically apply
--   its own <tt>Message-ID</tt> and <tt>Date</tt> headers; if you passed
--   these headers when creating the message, they will be overwritten by
--   the values that Amazon SES provides.</li>
--   <li>If you are using sending authorization to send on behalf of
--   another user, <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> enables you to specify the
--   cross-account identity for the email's Source, From, and Return-Path
--   parameters in one of two ways: you can pass optional parameters
--   <tt>SourceArn</tt>, <tt>FromArn</tt>, and/or <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt> to
--   the API, or you can include the following X-headers in the header of
--   your raw
--   email:<ul><li><pre>X-SES-SOURCE-ARN</pre></li><li><pre>X-SES-FROM-ARN</pre></li><li><pre>X-SES-RETURN-PATH-ARN</pre></li></ul>Don't
--   include these X-headers in the DKIM signature. Amazon SES removes
--   these before it sends the email.If you only specify the
--   <tt>SourceIdentityArn</tt> parameter, Amazon SES sets the From and
--   Return-Path addresses to the same identity that you specified.For more
--   information about sending authorization, see the <a>Using Sending
--   Authorization with Amazon SES</a> in the <i>Amazon SES Developer
--   Guide.</i></li>
--   <li>For every message that you send, the total number of recipients
--   (including each recipient in the To:, CC: and BCC: fields) is counted
--   against the maximum number of emails you can send in a 24-hour period
--   (your <i>sending quota</i>). For more information about sending quotas
--   in Amazon SES, see <a>Managing Your Amazon SES Sending Limits</a> in
--   the <i>Amazon SES Developer Guide.</i></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail

-- | Represents a request to send a single raw email using Amazon SES. For
--   more information, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSendRawEmail</a> smart constructor.
data SendRawEmail
SendRawEmail' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [MessageTag] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> RawMessage -> SendRawEmail

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to specify a particular "From" address in the
--   header of the raw email.
--   
--   Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header
--   <tt>X-SES-FROM-ARN</tt> in the raw message of the email. If you use
--   both the <tt>FromArn</tt> parameter and the corresponding X-header,
--   Amazon SES uses the value of the <tt>FromArn</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For information about when to use this parameter, see the description
--   of <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> in this guide, or see the <a>Amazon SES
--   Developer Guide</a>.
[$sel:fromArn:SendRawEmail'] :: SendRawEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | The identity's email address. If you do not provide a value for this
--   parameter, you must specify a "From" address in the raw text of the
--   message. (You can also specify both.)
--   
--   Amazon SES does not support the SMTPUTF8 extension, as described
--   in<a>RFC6531</a>. For this reason, the <i>local part</i> of a source
--   email address (the part of the email address that precedes the @ sign)
--   may only contain <a>7-bit ASCII characters</a>. If the <i>domain
--   part</i> of an address (the part after the @ sign) contains non-ASCII
--   characters, they must be encoded using Punycode, as described in
--   <a>RFC3492</a>. The sender name (also known as the <i>friendly
--   name</i>) may contain non-ASCII characters. These characters must be
--   encoded using MIME encoded-word syntax, as described in <a>RFC
--   2047</a>. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following form:
--   <tt>=?charset?encoding?encoded-text?=</tt>.
--   
--   If you specify the <tt>Source</tt> parameter and have feedback
--   forwarding enabled, then bounces and complaints will be sent to this
--   email address. This takes precedence over any Return-Path header that
--   you might include in the raw text of the message.
[$sel:source:SendRawEmail'] :: SendRawEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to use the email address specified in the
--   <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to use
--   <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>ReturnPath</tt> to be <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header
--   <tt>X-SES-RETURN-PATH-ARN</tt> in the raw message of the email. If you
--   use both the <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt> parameter and the corresponding
--   X-header, Amazon SES uses the value of the <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt>
--   parameter.
--   
--   For information about when to use this parameter, see the description
--   of <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> in this guide, or see the <a>Amazon SES
--   Developer Guide</a>.
[$sel:returnPathArn:SendRawEmail'] :: SendRawEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | A list of destinations for the message, consisting of To:, CC:, and
--   BCC: addresses.
[$sel:destinations:SendRawEmail'] :: SendRawEmail -> Maybe [Text]

-- | A list of tags, in the form of name/value pairs, to apply to an email
--   that you send using <tt>SendRawEmail</tt>. Tags correspond to
--   characteristics of the email that you define, so that you can publish
--   email sending events.
[$sel:tags:SendRawEmail'] :: SendRawEmail -> Maybe [MessageTag]

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to send for the email address specified in the
--   <tt>Source</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to send from
--   <tt>user@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>SourceArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>Source</tt> to be <tt>user@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header
--   <tt>X-SES-SOURCE-ARN</tt> in the raw message of the email. If you use
--   both the <tt>SourceArn</tt> parameter and the corresponding X-header,
--   Amazon SES uses the value of the <tt>SourceArn</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For information about when to use this parameter, see the description
--   of <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> in this guide, or see the <a>Amazon SES
--   Developer Guide</a>.
[$sel:sourceArn:SendRawEmail'] :: SendRawEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the configuration set to use when you send an email using
--   <tt>SendRawEmail</tt>.
[$sel:configurationSetName:SendRawEmail'] :: SendRawEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | The raw email message itself. The message has to meet the following
--   criteria:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The message has to contain a header and a body, separated by a
--   blank line.</li>
--   <li>All of the required header fields must be present in the
--   message.</li>
--   <li>Each part of a multipart MIME message must be formatted
--   properly.</li>
--   <li>Attachments must be of a content type that Amazon SES supports.
--   For a list on unsupported content types, see <a>Unsupported Attachment
--   Types</a> in the <i>Amazon SES Developer Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>The entire message must be base64-encoded.</li>
--   <li>If any of the MIME parts in your message contain content that is
--   outside of the 7-bit ASCII character range, we highly recommend that
--   you encode that content. For more information, see <a>Sending Raw
--   Email</a> in the <i>Amazon SES Developer Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>Per <a>RFC 5321</a>, the maximum length of each line of text,
--   including the &lt;CRLF&gt;, must not exceed 1,000 characters.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:rawMessage:SendRawEmail'] :: SendRawEmail -> RawMessage

-- | Create a value of <a>SendRawEmail</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromArn:SendRawEmail'</a>, <a>sendRawEmail_fromArn</a> - This
--   parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the
--   identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that
--   permits you to specify a particular "From" address in the header of
--   the raw email.
--   
--   Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header
--   <tt>X-SES-FROM-ARN</tt> in the raw message of the email. If you use
--   both the <tt>FromArn</tt> parameter and the corresponding X-header,
--   Amazon SES uses the value of the <tt>FromArn</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For information about when to use this parameter, see the description
--   of <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> in this guide, or see the <a>Amazon SES
--   Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:source:SendRawEmail'</a>, <a>sendRawEmail_source</a> - The
--   identity's email address. If you do not provide a value for this
--   parameter, you must specify a "From" address in the raw text of the
--   message. (You can also specify both.)
--   
--   Amazon SES does not support the SMTPUTF8 extension, as described
--   in<a>RFC6531</a>. For this reason, the <i>local part</i> of a source
--   email address (the part of the email address that precedes the @ sign)
--   may only contain <a>7-bit ASCII characters</a>. If the <i>domain
--   part</i> of an address (the part after the @ sign) contains non-ASCII
--   characters, they must be encoded using Punycode, as described in
--   <a>RFC3492</a>. The sender name (also known as the <i>friendly
--   name</i>) may contain non-ASCII characters. These characters must be
--   encoded using MIME encoded-word syntax, as described in <a>RFC
--   2047</a>. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following form:
--   <tt>=?charset?encoding?encoded-text?=</tt>.
--   
--   If you specify the <tt>Source</tt> parameter and have feedback
--   forwarding enabled, then bounces and complaints will be sent to this
--   email address. This takes precedence over any Return-Path header that
--   you might include in the raw text of the message.
--   
--   <a>$sel:returnPathArn:SendRawEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendRawEmail_returnPathArn</a> - This parameter is used only for
--   sending authorization. It is the ARN of the identity that is
--   associated with the sending authorization policy that permits you to
--   use the email address specified in the <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to use
--   <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>ReturnPath</tt> to be <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header
--   <tt>X-SES-RETURN-PATH-ARN</tt> in the raw message of the email. If you
--   use both the <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt> parameter and the corresponding
--   X-header, Amazon SES uses the value of the <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt>
--   parameter.
--   
--   For information about when to use this parameter, see the description
--   of <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> in this guide, or see the <a>Amazon SES
--   Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinations:SendRawEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendRawEmail_destinations</a> - A list of destinations for the
--   message, consisting of To:, CC:, and BCC: addresses.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:SendRawEmail'</a>, <a>sendRawEmail_tags</a> - A list of
--   tags, in the form of name/value pairs, to apply to an email that you
--   send using <tt>SendRawEmail</tt>. Tags correspond to characteristics
--   of the email that you define, so that you can publish email sending
--   events.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceArn:SendRawEmail'</a>, <a>sendRawEmail_sourceArn</a> -
--   This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to send for the email address specified in the
--   <tt>Source</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to send from
--   <tt>user@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>SourceArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>Source</tt> to be <tt>user@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header
--   <tt>X-SES-SOURCE-ARN</tt> in the raw message of the email. If you use
--   both the <tt>SourceArn</tt> parameter and the corresponding X-header,
--   Amazon SES uses the value of the <tt>SourceArn</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For information about when to use this parameter, see the description
--   of <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> in this guide, or see the <a>Amazon SES
--   Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:configurationSetName:SendRawEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendRawEmail_configurationSetName</a> - The name of the
--   configuration set to use when you send an email using
--   <tt>SendRawEmail</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:rawMessage:SendRawEmail'</a>, <a>sendRawEmail_rawMessage</a> -
--   The raw email message itself. The message has to meet the following
--   criteria:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The message has to contain a header and a body, separated by a
--   blank line.</li>
--   <li>All of the required header fields must be present in the
--   message.</li>
--   <li>Each part of a multipart MIME message must be formatted
--   properly.</li>
--   <li>Attachments must be of a content type that Amazon SES supports.
--   For a list on unsupported content types, see <a>Unsupported Attachment
--   Types</a> in the <i>Amazon SES Developer Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>The entire message must be base64-encoded.</li>
--   <li>If any of the MIME parts in your message contain content that is
--   outside of the 7-bit ASCII character range, we highly recommend that
--   you encode that content. For more information, see <a>Sending Raw
--   Email</a> in the <i>Amazon SES Developer Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>Per <a>RFC 5321</a>, the maximum length of each line of text,
--   including the &lt;CRLF&gt;, must not exceed 1,000 characters.</li>
--   </ul>
newSendRawEmail :: RawMessage -> SendRawEmail

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to specify a particular "From" address in the
--   header of the raw email.
--   
--   Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header
--   <tt>X-SES-FROM-ARN</tt> in the raw message of the email. If you use
--   both the <tt>FromArn</tt> parameter and the corresponding X-header,
--   Amazon SES uses the value of the <tt>FromArn</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For information about when to use this parameter, see the description
--   of <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> in this guide, or see the <a>Amazon SES
--   Developer Guide</a>.
sendRawEmail_fromArn :: Lens' SendRawEmail (Maybe Text)

-- | The identity's email address. If you do not provide a value for this
--   parameter, you must specify a "From" address in the raw text of the
--   message. (You can also specify both.)
--   
--   Amazon SES does not support the SMTPUTF8 extension, as described
--   in<a>RFC6531</a>. For this reason, the <i>local part</i> of a source
--   email address (the part of the email address that precedes the @ sign)
--   may only contain <a>7-bit ASCII characters</a>. If the <i>domain
--   part</i> of an address (the part after the @ sign) contains non-ASCII
--   characters, they must be encoded using Punycode, as described in
--   <a>RFC3492</a>. The sender name (also known as the <i>friendly
--   name</i>) may contain non-ASCII characters. These characters must be
--   encoded using MIME encoded-word syntax, as described in <a>RFC
--   2047</a>. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following form:
--   <tt>=?charset?encoding?encoded-text?=</tt>.
--   
--   If you specify the <tt>Source</tt> parameter and have feedback
--   forwarding enabled, then bounces and complaints will be sent to this
--   email address. This takes precedence over any Return-Path header that
--   you might include in the raw text of the message.
sendRawEmail_source :: Lens' SendRawEmail (Maybe Text)

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to use the email address specified in the
--   <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to use
--   <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>ReturnPath</tt> to be <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header
--   <tt>X-SES-RETURN-PATH-ARN</tt> in the raw message of the email. If you
--   use both the <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt> parameter and the corresponding
--   X-header, Amazon SES uses the value of the <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt>
--   parameter.
--   
--   For information about when to use this parameter, see the description
--   of <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> in this guide, or see the <a>Amazon SES
--   Developer Guide</a>.
sendRawEmail_returnPathArn :: Lens' SendRawEmail (Maybe Text)

-- | A list of destinations for the message, consisting of To:, CC:, and
--   BCC: addresses.
sendRawEmail_destinations :: Lens' SendRawEmail (Maybe [Text])

-- | A list of tags, in the form of name/value pairs, to apply to an email
--   that you send using <tt>SendRawEmail</tt>. Tags correspond to
--   characteristics of the email that you define, so that you can publish
--   email sending events.
sendRawEmail_tags :: Lens' SendRawEmail (Maybe [MessageTag])

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to send for the email address specified in the
--   <tt>Source</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to send from
--   <tt>user@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>SourceArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>Source</tt> to be <tt>user@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header
--   <tt>X-SES-SOURCE-ARN</tt> in the raw message of the email. If you use
--   both the <tt>SourceArn</tt> parameter and the corresponding X-header,
--   Amazon SES uses the value of the <tt>SourceArn</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For information about when to use this parameter, see the description
--   of <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> in this guide, or see the <a>Amazon SES
--   Developer Guide</a>.
sendRawEmail_sourceArn :: Lens' SendRawEmail (Maybe Text)

-- | The name of the configuration set to use when you send an email using
--   <tt>SendRawEmail</tt>.
sendRawEmail_configurationSetName :: Lens' SendRawEmail (Maybe Text)

-- | The raw email message itself. The message has to meet the following
--   criteria:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The message has to contain a header and a body, separated by a
--   blank line.</li>
--   <li>All of the required header fields must be present in the
--   message.</li>
--   <li>Each part of a multipart MIME message must be formatted
--   properly.</li>
--   <li>Attachments must be of a content type that Amazon SES supports.
--   For a list on unsupported content types, see <a>Unsupported Attachment
--   Types</a> in the <i>Amazon SES Developer Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>The entire message must be base64-encoded.</li>
--   <li>If any of the MIME parts in your message contain content that is
--   outside of the 7-bit ASCII character range, we highly recommend that
--   you encode that content. For more information, see <a>Sending Raw
--   Email</a> in the <i>Amazon SES Developer Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>Per <a>RFC 5321</a>, the maximum length of each line of text,
--   including the &lt;CRLF&gt;, must not exceed 1,000 characters.</li>
--   </ul>
sendRawEmail_rawMessage :: Lens' SendRawEmail RawMessage

-- | Represents a unique message ID.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSendRawEmailResponse</a> smart constructor.
data SendRawEmailResponse
SendRawEmailResponse' :: Int -> Text -> SendRawEmailResponse

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:SendRawEmailResponse'] :: SendRawEmailResponse -> Int

-- | The unique message identifier returned from the <tt>SendRawEmail</tt>
--   action.
[$sel:messageId:SendRawEmailResponse'] :: SendRawEmailResponse -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>SendRawEmailResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:SendRawEmailResponse'</a>,
--   <a>sendRawEmailResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status
--   code.
--   
--   <a>$sel:messageId:SendRawEmailResponse'</a>,
--   <a>sendRawEmailResponse_messageId</a> - The unique message identifier
--   returned from the <tt>SendRawEmail</tt> action.
newSendRawEmailResponse :: Int -> Text -> SendRawEmailResponse

-- | The response's http status code.
sendRawEmailResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' SendRawEmailResponse Int

-- | The unique message identifier returned from the <tt>SendRawEmail</tt>
--   action.
sendRawEmailResponse_messageId :: Lens' SendRawEmailResponse Text
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmail
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmail
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmail
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmail
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmailResponse
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmailResponse
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmailResponse
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmailResponse
instance Network.AWS.Types.AWSRequest Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmail
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmailResponse
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmail
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmail
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeaders Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmail
instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmail
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.SES.SendRawEmail.SendRawEmail


-- | Composes an email message and immediately queues it for sending. In
--   order to send email using the <tt>SendEmail</tt> operation, your
--   message must meet the following requirements:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The message must be sent from a verified email address or domain.
--   If you attempt to send email using a non-verified address or domain,
--   the operation will result in an "Email address not verified"
--   error.</li>
--   <li>If your account is still in the Amazon SES sandbox, you may only
--   send to verified addresses or domains, or to email addresses
--   associated with the Amazon SES Mailbox Simulator. For more
--   information, see <a>Verifying Email Addresses and Domains</a> in the
--   <i>Amazon SES Developer Guide.</i></li>
--   <li>The maximum message size is 10 MB.</li>
--   <li>The message must include at least one recipient email address. The
--   recipient address can be a To: address, a CC: address, or a BCC:
--   address. If a recipient email address is invalid (that is, it is not
--   in the format <i>UserName@[SubDomain.]Domain.TopLevelDomain</i>), the
--   entire message will be rejected, even if the message contains other
--   recipients that are valid.</li>
--   <li>The message may not include more than 50 recipients, across the
--   To:, CC: and BCC: fields. If you need to send an email message to a
--   larger audience, you can divide your recipient list into groups of 50
--   or fewer, and then call the <tt>SendEmail</tt> operation several times
--   to send the message to each group.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For every message that you send, the total number of recipients
--   (including each recipient in the To:, CC: and BCC: fields) is counted
--   against the maximum number of emails you can send in a 24-hour period
--   (your <i>sending quota</i>). For more information about sending quotas
--   in Amazon SES, see <a>Managing Your Amazon SES Sending Limits</a> in
--   the <i>Amazon SES Developer Guide.</i>
module Network.AWS.SES.SendEmail

-- | Represents a request to send a single formatted email using Amazon
--   SES. For more information, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSendEmail</a> smart constructor.
data SendEmail
SendEmail' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [MessageTag] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Destination -> Message -> SendEmail

-- | The email address that bounces and complaints will be forwarded to
--   when feedback forwarding is enabled. If the message cannot be
--   delivered to the recipient, then an error message will be returned
--   from the recipient's ISP; this message will then be forwarded to the
--   email address specified by the <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter. The
--   <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter is never overwritten. This email address
--   must be either individually verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain
--   that has been verified with Amazon SES.
[$sel:returnPath:SendEmail'] :: SendEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to use the email address specified in the
--   <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to use
--   <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>ReturnPath</tt> to be <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   For more information about sending authorization, see the <a>Amazon
--   SES Developer Guide</a>.
[$sel:returnPathArn:SendEmail'] :: SendEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | A list of tags, in the form of name/value pairs, to apply to an email
--   that you send using <tt>SendEmail</tt>. Tags correspond to
--   characteristics of the email that you define, so that you can publish
--   email sending events.
[$sel:tags:SendEmail'] :: SendEmail -> Maybe [MessageTag]

-- | The reply-to email address(es) for the message. If the recipient
--   replies to the message, each reply-to address will receive the reply.
[$sel:replyToAddresses:SendEmail'] :: SendEmail -> Maybe [Text]

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to send for the email address specified in the
--   <tt>Source</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to send from
--   <tt>user@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>SourceArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>Source</tt> to be <tt>user@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   For more information about sending authorization, see the <a>Amazon
--   SES Developer Guide</a>.
[$sel:sourceArn:SendEmail'] :: SendEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the configuration set to use when you send an email using
--   <tt>SendEmail</tt>.
[$sel:configurationSetName:SendEmail'] :: SendEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | The email address that is sending the email. This email address must
--   be either individually verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain that
--   has been verified with Amazon SES. For information about verifying
--   identities, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   If you are sending on behalf of another user and have been permitted
--   to do so by a sending authorization policy, then you must also specify
--   the <tt>SourceArn</tt> parameter. For more information about sending
--   authorization, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   Amazon SES does not support the SMTPUTF8 extension, as described in
--   <a>RFC6531</a>. For this reason, the <i>local part</i> of a source
--   email address (the part of the email address that precedes the @ sign)
--   may only contain <a>7-bit ASCII characters</a>. If the <i>domain
--   part</i> of an address (the part after the @ sign) contains non-ASCII
--   characters, they must be encoded using Punycode, as described in
--   <a>RFC3492</a>. The sender name (also known as the <i>friendly
--   name</i>) may contain non-ASCII characters. These characters must be
--   encoded using MIME encoded-word syntax, as described in <a>RFC
--   2047</a>. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following form:
--   <tt>=?charset?encoding?encoded-text?=</tt>.
[$sel:source:SendEmail'] :: SendEmail -> Text

-- | The destination for this email, composed of To:, CC:, and BCC: fields.
[$sel:destination:SendEmail'] :: SendEmail -> Destination

-- | The message to be sent.
[$sel:message:SendEmail'] :: SendEmail -> Message

-- | Create a value of <a>SendEmail</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:returnPath:SendEmail'</a>, <a>sendEmail_returnPath</a> - The
--   email address that bounces and complaints will be forwarded to when
--   feedback forwarding is enabled. If the message cannot be delivered to
--   the recipient, then an error message will be returned from the
--   recipient's ISP; this message will then be forwarded to the email
--   address specified by the <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter. The
--   <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter is never overwritten. This email address
--   must be either individually verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain
--   that has been verified with Amazon SES.
--   
--   <a>$sel:returnPathArn:SendEmail'</a>, <a>sendEmail_returnPathArn</a> -
--   This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to use the email address specified in the
--   <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to use
--   <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>ReturnPath</tt> to be <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   For more information about sending authorization, see the <a>Amazon
--   SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:SendEmail'</a>, <a>sendEmail_tags</a> - A list of tags,
--   in the form of name/value pairs, to apply to an email that you send
--   using <tt>SendEmail</tt>. Tags correspond to characteristics of the
--   email that you define, so that you can publish email sending events.
--   
--   <a>$sel:replyToAddresses:SendEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendEmail_replyToAddresses</a> - The reply-to email address(es) for
--   the message. If the recipient replies to the message, each reply-to
--   address will receive the reply.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceArn:SendEmail'</a>, <a>sendEmail_sourceArn</a> - This
--   parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the
--   identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that
--   permits you to send for the email address specified in the
--   <tt>Source</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to send from
--   <tt>user@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>SourceArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>Source</tt> to be <tt>user@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   For more information about sending authorization, see the <a>Amazon
--   SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:configurationSetName:SendEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendEmail_configurationSetName</a> - The name of the configuration
--   set to use when you send an email using <tt>SendEmail</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:source:SendEmail'</a>, <a>sendEmail_source</a> - The email
--   address that is sending the email. This email address must be either
--   individually verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain that has been
--   verified with Amazon SES. For information about verifying identities,
--   see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   If you are sending on behalf of another user and have been permitted
--   to do so by a sending authorization policy, then you must also specify
--   the <tt>SourceArn</tt> parameter. For more information about sending
--   authorization, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   Amazon SES does not support the SMTPUTF8 extension, as described in
--   <a>RFC6531</a>. For this reason, the <i>local part</i> of a source
--   email address (the part of the email address that precedes the @ sign)
--   may only contain <a>7-bit ASCII characters</a>. If the <i>domain
--   part</i> of an address (the part after the @ sign) contains non-ASCII
--   characters, they must be encoded using Punycode, as described in
--   <a>RFC3492</a>. The sender name (also known as the <i>friendly
--   name</i>) may contain non-ASCII characters. These characters must be
--   encoded using MIME encoded-word syntax, as described in <a>RFC
--   2047</a>. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following form:
--   <tt>=?charset?encoding?encoded-text?=</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:destination:SendEmail'</a>, <a>sendEmail_destination</a> - The
--   destination for this email, composed of To:, CC:, and BCC: fields.
--   
--   <a>$sel:message:SendEmail'</a>, <a>sendEmail_message</a> - The message
--   to be sent.
newSendEmail :: Text -> Destination -> Message -> SendEmail

-- | The email address that bounces and complaints will be forwarded to
--   when feedback forwarding is enabled. If the message cannot be
--   delivered to the recipient, then an error message will be returned
--   from the recipient's ISP; this message will then be forwarded to the
--   email address specified by the <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter. The
--   <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter is never overwritten. This email address
--   must be either individually verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain
--   that has been verified with Amazon SES.
sendEmail_returnPath :: Lens' SendEmail (Maybe Text)

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to use the email address specified in the
--   <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to use
--   <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>ReturnPath</tt> to be <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   For more information about sending authorization, see the <a>Amazon
--   SES Developer Guide</a>.
sendEmail_returnPathArn :: Lens' SendEmail (Maybe Text)

-- | A list of tags, in the form of name/value pairs, to apply to an email
--   that you send using <tt>SendEmail</tt>. Tags correspond to
--   characteristics of the email that you define, so that you can publish
--   email sending events.
sendEmail_tags :: Lens' SendEmail (Maybe [MessageTag])

-- | The reply-to email address(es) for the message. If the recipient
--   replies to the message, each reply-to address will receive the reply.
sendEmail_replyToAddresses :: Lens' SendEmail (Maybe [Text])

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to send for the email address specified in the
--   <tt>Source</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to send from
--   <tt>user@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>SourceArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>Source</tt> to be <tt>user@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   For more information about sending authorization, see the <a>Amazon
--   SES Developer Guide</a>.
sendEmail_sourceArn :: Lens' SendEmail (Maybe Text)

-- | The name of the configuration set to use when you send an email using
--   <tt>SendEmail</tt>.
sendEmail_configurationSetName :: Lens' SendEmail (Maybe Text)

-- | The email address that is sending the email. This email address must
--   be either individually verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain that
--   has been verified with Amazon SES. For information about verifying
--   identities, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   If you are sending on behalf of another user and have been permitted
--   to do so by a sending authorization policy, then you must also specify
--   the <tt>SourceArn</tt> parameter. For more information about sending
--   authorization, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   Amazon SES does not support the SMTPUTF8 extension, as described in
--   <a>RFC6531</a>. For this reason, the <i>local part</i> of a source
--   email address (the part of the email address that precedes the @ sign)
--   may only contain <a>7-bit ASCII characters</a>. If the <i>domain
--   part</i> of an address (the part after the @ sign) contains non-ASCII
--   characters, they must be encoded using Punycode, as described in
--   <a>RFC3492</a>. The sender name (also known as the <i>friendly
--   name</i>) may contain non-ASCII characters. These characters must be
--   encoded using MIME encoded-word syntax, as described in <a>RFC
--   2047</a>. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following form:
--   <tt>=?charset?encoding?encoded-text?=</tt>.
sendEmail_source :: Lens' SendEmail Text

-- | The destination for this email, composed of To:, CC:, and BCC: fields.
sendEmail_destination :: Lens' SendEmail Destination

-- | The message to be sent.
sendEmail_message :: Lens' SendEmail Message

-- | Represents a unique message ID.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSendEmailResponse</a> smart constructor.
data SendEmailResponse
SendEmailResponse' :: Int -> Text -> SendEmailResponse

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:SendEmailResponse'] :: SendEmailResponse -> Int

-- | The unique message identifier returned from the <tt>SendEmail</tt>
--   action.
[$sel:messageId:SendEmailResponse'] :: SendEmailResponse -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>SendEmailResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:SendEmailResponse'</a>,
--   <a>sendEmailResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status code.
--   
--   <a>$sel:messageId:SendEmailResponse'</a>,
--   <a>sendEmailResponse_messageId</a> - The unique message identifier
--   returned from the <tt>SendEmail</tt> action.
newSendEmailResponse :: Int -> Text -> SendEmailResponse

-- | The response's http status code.
sendEmailResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' SendEmailResponse Int

-- | The unique message identifier returned from the <tt>SendEmail</tt>
--   action.
sendEmailResponse_messageId :: Lens' SendEmailResponse Text
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.SES.SendEmail.SendEmail
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.SES.SendEmail.SendEmail
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.SES.SendEmail.SendEmail
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.SES.SendEmail.SendEmail
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.SES.SendEmail.SendEmailResponse
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.SES.SendEmail.SendEmailResponse
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.SES.SendEmail.SendEmailResponse
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.SES.SendEmail.SendEmailResponse
instance Network.AWS.Types.AWSRequest Network.AWS.SES.SendEmail.SendEmail
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.SES.SendEmail.SendEmailResponse
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.SES.SendEmail.SendEmail

-- | Adds an email address to the list of identities for your Amazon SES
--   account in the current AWS Region and attempts to verify it. As a
--   result of executing this operation, a customized verification email is
--   sent to the specified address.
--   
--   To use this operation, you must first create a custom verification
--   email template. For more information about creating and using custom
--   verification email templates, see <a>Using Custom Verification Email
--   Templates</a> in the <i>Amazon SES Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   You can execute this operation no more than once per second.
module Network.AWS.SES.SendCustomVerificationEmail

-- | Represents a request to send a custom verification email to a
--   specified recipient.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSendCustomVerificationEmail</a> smart constructor.
data SendCustomVerificationEmail
SendCustomVerificationEmail' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> SendCustomVerificationEmail

-- | Name of a configuration set to use when sending the verification
--   email.
[$sel:configurationSetName:SendCustomVerificationEmail'] :: SendCustomVerificationEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | The email address to verify.
[$sel:emailAddress:SendCustomVerificationEmail'] :: SendCustomVerificationEmail -> Text

-- | The name of the custom verification email template to use when sending
--   the verification email.
[$sel:templateName:SendCustomVerificationEmail'] :: SendCustomVerificationEmail -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>SendCustomVerificationEmail</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:configurationSetName:SendCustomVerificationEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendCustomVerificationEmail_configurationSetName</a> - Name of a
--   configuration set to use when sending the verification email.
--   
--   <a>$sel:emailAddress:SendCustomVerificationEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendCustomVerificationEmail_emailAddress</a> - The email address to
--   verify.
--   
--   <a>$sel:templateName:SendCustomVerificationEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendCustomVerificationEmail_templateName</a> - The name of the
--   custom verification email template to use when sending the
--   verification email.
newSendCustomVerificationEmail :: Text -> Text -> SendCustomVerificationEmail

-- | Name of a configuration set to use when sending the verification
--   email.
sendCustomVerificationEmail_configurationSetName :: Lens' SendCustomVerificationEmail (Maybe Text)

-- | The email address to verify.
sendCustomVerificationEmail_emailAddress :: Lens' SendCustomVerificationEmail Text

-- | The name of the custom verification email template to use when sending
--   the verification email.
sendCustomVerificationEmail_templateName :: Lens' SendCustomVerificationEmail Text

-- | The response received when attempting to send the custom verification
--   email.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSendCustomVerificationEmailResponse</a> smart
--   constructor.
data SendCustomVerificationEmailResponse
SendCustomVerificationEmailResponse' :: Maybe Text -> Int -> SendCustomVerificationEmailResponse

--   <tt>SendCustomVerificationEmail</tt> operation.
[$sel:messageId:SendCustomVerificationEmailResponse'] :: SendCustomVerificationEmailResponse -> Maybe Text

[$sel:httpStatus:SendCustomVerificationEmailResponse'] :: SendCustomVerificationEmailResponse -> Int

--   optional fields omitted.

--   fields.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   <a>sendCustomVerificationEmailResponse_messageId</a> - The unique
--   message identifier returned from the
--   <tt>SendCustomVerificationEmail</tt> operation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:SendCustomVerificationEmailResponse'</a>,
--   <a>sendCustomVerificationEmailResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's
--   http status code.
newSendCustomVerificationEmailResponse :: Int -> SendCustomVerificationEmailResponse

--   <tt>SendCustomVerificationEmail</tt> operation.
sendCustomVerificationEmailResponse_messageId :: Lens' SendCustomVerificationEmailResponse (Maybe Text)

sendCustomVerificationEmailResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' SendCustomVerificationEmailResponse Int

instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.SES.SendCustomVerificationEmail.SendCustomVerificationEmail


-- | Composes an email message to multiple destinations. The message body
--   is created using an email template.
--   
--   In order to send email using the <tt>SendBulkTemplatedEmail</tt>
--   operation, your call to the API must meet the following requirements:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The call must refer to an existing email template. You can create
--   email templates using the CreateTemplate operation.</li>
--   <li>The message must be sent from a verified email address or
--   domain.</li>
--   <li>If your account is still in the Amazon SES sandbox, you may only
--   send to verified addresses or domains, or to email addresses
--   associated with the Amazon SES Mailbox Simulator. For more
--   information, see <a>Verifying Email Addresses and Domains</a> in the
--   <i>Amazon SES Developer Guide.</i></li>
--   <li>The maximum message size is 10 MB.</li>
--   <li>Each <tt>Destination</tt> parameter must include at least one
--   recipient email address. The recipient address can be a To: address, a
--   CC: address, or a BCC: address. If a recipient email address is
--   invalid (that is, it is not in the format
--   <i>UserName@[SubDomain.]Domain.TopLevelDomain</i>), the entire message
--   will be rejected, even if the message contains other recipients that
--   are valid.</li>
--   <li>The message may not include more than 50 recipients, across the
--   To:, CC: and BCC: fields. If you need to send an email message to a
--   larger audience, you can divide your recipient list into groups of 50
--   or fewer, and then call the <tt>SendBulkTemplatedEmail</tt> operation
--   several times to send the message to each group.</li>
--   <li>The number of destinations you can contact in a single call to the
--   API may be limited by your account's maximum sending rate.</li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.SES.SendBulkTemplatedEmail

-- | Represents a request to send a templated email to multiple
--   destinations using Amazon SES. For more information, see the <a>Amazon
--   SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSendBulkTemplatedEmail</a> smart constructor.
data SendBulkTemplatedEmail
SendBulkTemplatedEmail' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [MessageTag] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> [BulkEmailDestination] -> SendBulkTemplatedEmail

-- | The email address that bounces and complaints will be forwarded to
--   when feedback forwarding is enabled. If the message cannot be
--   delivered to the recipient, then an error message will be returned
--   from the recipient's ISP; this message will then be forwarded to the
--   email address specified by the <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter. The
--   <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter is never overwritten. This email address
--   must be either individually verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain
--   that has been verified with Amazon SES.
[$sel:returnPath:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'] :: SendBulkTemplatedEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | A list of replacement values to apply to the template when replacement
--   data is not specified in a Destination object. These values act as a
--   default or fallback option when no other data is available.
--   
--   The template data is a JSON object, typically consisting of key-value
--   pairs in which the keys correspond to replacement tags in the email
--   template.
[$sel:defaultTemplateData:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'] :: SendBulkTemplatedEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to use the email address specified in the
--   <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to use
--   <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>ReturnPath</tt> to be <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   For more information about sending authorization, see the <a>Amazon
--   SES Developer Guide</a>.
[$sel:returnPathArn:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'] :: SendBulkTemplatedEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | A list of tags, in the form of name/value pairs, to apply to an email
--   that you send to a destination using <tt>SendBulkTemplatedEmail</tt>.
[$sel:defaultTags:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'] :: SendBulkTemplatedEmail -> Maybe [MessageTag]

-- | The reply-to email address(es) for the message. If the recipient
--   replies to the message, each reply-to address will receive the reply.
[$sel:replyToAddresses:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'] :: SendBulkTemplatedEmail -> Maybe [Text]

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to send for the email address specified in the
--   <tt>Source</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to send from
--   <tt>user@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>SourceArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>Source</tt> to be <tt>user@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   For more information about sending authorization, see the <a>Amazon
--   SES Developer Guide</a>.
[$sel:sourceArn:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'] :: SendBulkTemplatedEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the configuration set to use when you send an email using
--   <tt>SendBulkTemplatedEmail</tt>.
[$sel:configurationSetName:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'] :: SendBulkTemplatedEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | The ARN of the template to use when sending this email.
[$sel:templateArn:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'] :: SendBulkTemplatedEmail -> Maybe Text

-- | The email address that is sending the email. This email address must
--   be either individually verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain that
--   has been verified with Amazon SES. For information about verifying
--   identities, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   If you are sending on behalf of another user and have been permitted
--   to do so by a sending authorization policy, then you must also specify
--   the <tt>SourceArn</tt> parameter. For more information about sending
--   authorization, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   Amazon SES does not support the SMTPUTF8 extension, as described in
--   <a>RFC6531</a>. For this reason, the <i>local part</i> of a source
--   email address (the part of the email address that precedes the @ sign)
--   may only contain <a>7-bit ASCII characters</a>. If the <i>domain
--   part</i> of an address (the part after the @ sign) contains non-ASCII
--   characters, they must be encoded using Punycode, as described in
--   <a>RFC3492</a>. The sender name (also known as the <i>friendly
--   name</i>) may contain non-ASCII characters. These characters must be
--   encoded using MIME encoded-word syntax, as described in <a>RFC
--   2047</a>. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following form:
--   <tt>=?charset?encoding?encoded-text?=</tt>.
[$sel:source:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'] :: SendBulkTemplatedEmail -> Text

-- | The template to use when sending this email.
[$sel:template:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'] :: SendBulkTemplatedEmail -> Text

-- | One or more <tt>Destination</tt> objects. All of the recipients in a
--   <tt>Destination</tt> will receive the same version of the email. You
--   can specify up to 50 <tt>Destination</tt> objects within a
--   <tt>Destinations</tt> array.
[$sel:destinations:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'] :: SendBulkTemplatedEmail -> [BulkEmailDestination]

-- | Create a value of <a>SendBulkTemplatedEmail</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:returnPath:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendBulkTemplatedEmail_returnPath</a> - The email address that
--   bounces and complaints will be forwarded to when feedback forwarding
--   is enabled. If the message cannot be delivered to the recipient, then
--   an error message will be returned from the recipient's ISP; this
--   message will then be forwarded to the email address specified by the
--   <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter. The <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter is
--   never overwritten. This email address must be either individually
--   verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain that has been verified with
--   Amazon SES.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultTemplateData:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendBulkTemplatedEmail_defaultTemplateData</a> - A list of
--   replacement values to apply to the template when replacement data is
--   not specified in a Destination object. These values act as a default
--   or fallback option when no other data is available.
--   
--   The template data is a JSON object, typically consisting of key-value
--   pairs in which the keys correspond to replacement tags in the email
--   template.
--

--   <a>sendBulkTemplatedEmail_returnPathArn</a> - This parameter is used

--   associated with the sending authorization policy that permits you to
--   use the email address specified in the <tt>ReturnPath</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)

--   <tt>feedback@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>ReturnPathArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and

--   For more information about sending authorization, see the <a>Amazon

--

--   address(es) for the message. If the recipient replies to the message,
--   each reply-to address will receive the reply.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceArn:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendBulkTemplatedEmail_sourceArn</a> - This parameter is used only
--   for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the identity that is
--   associated with the sending authorization policy that permits you to
--   send for the email address specified in the <tt>Source</tt> parameter.
--   
--   For example, if the owner of <tt>example.com</tt> (which has ARN
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>)
--   attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to send from
--   <tt>user@example.com</tt>, then you would specify the
--   <tt>SourceArn</tt> to be
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>, and
--   the <tt>Source</tt> to be <tt>user@example.com</tt>.
--   
--   For more information about sending authorization, see the <a>Amazon
--   SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:configurationSetName:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendBulkTemplatedEmail_configurationSetName</a> - The name of the
--   configuration set to use when you send an email using
--   <tt>SendBulkTemplatedEmail</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:templateArn:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendBulkTemplatedEmail_templateArn</a> - The ARN of the template to
--   use when sending this email.
--   
--   <a>$sel:source:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendBulkTemplatedEmail_source</a> - The email address that is
--   sending the email. This email address must be either individually
--   verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain that has been verified with
--   Amazon SES. For information about verifying identities, see the
--   <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   If you are sending on behalf of another user and have been permitted
--   to do so by a sending authorization policy, then you must also specify
--   the <tt>SourceArn</tt> parameter. For more information about sending
--   authorization, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   Amazon SES does not support the SMTPUTF8 extension, as described in
--   <a>RFC6531</a>. For this reason, the <i>local part</i> of a source
--   email address (the part of the email address that precedes the @ sign)

--   part</i> of an address (the part after the @ sign) contains non-ASCII
--   characters, they must be encoded using Punycode, as described in
--   <a>RFC3492</a>. The sender name (also known as the <i>friendly
--   name</i>) may contain non-ASCII characters. These characters must be
--   encoded using MIME encoded-word syntax, as described in <a>RFC
--   2047</a>. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following form:
--   <tt>=?charset?encoding?encoded-text?=</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:template:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendBulkTemplatedEmail_template</a> - The template to use when
--   sending this email.
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinations:SendBulkTemplatedEmail'</a>,
--   <a>sendBulkTemplatedEmail_destinations</a> - One or more
--   <tt>Destination</tt> objects. All of the recipients in a
--   <tt>Destination</tt> will receive the same version of the email. You
--   can specify up to 50 <tt>Destination</tt> objects within a
--   <tt>Destinations</tt> array.
newSendBulkTemplatedEmail :: Text -> Text -> SendBulkTemplatedEmail

-- | The email address that bounces and complaints will be forwarded to

-- | The name of the configuration set to use when you send an email using
--   <tt>SendBulkTemplatedEmail</tt>.
sendBulkTemplatedEmail_configurationSetName :: Lens' SendBulkTemplatedEmail (Maybe Text)

-- | The ARN of the template to use when sending this email.
sendBulkTemplatedEmail_templateArn :: Lens' SendBulkTemplatedEmail (Maybe Text)

-- | The email address that is sending the email. This email address must
--   be either individually verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain that
--   has been verified with Amazon SES. For information about verifying
--   identities, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   If you are sending on behalf of another user and have been permitted
--   to do so by a sending authorization policy, then you must also specify
--   the <tt>SourceArn</tt> parameter. For more information about sending
--   authorization, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   Amazon SES does not support the SMTPUTF8 extension, as described in
--   <a>RFC6531</a>. For this reason, the <i>local part</i> of a source
--   email address (the part of the email address that precedes the @ sign)
--   may only contain <a>7-bit ASCII characters</a>. If the <i>domain
--   part</i> of an address (the part after the @ sign) contains non-ASCII
--   characters, they must be encoded using Punycode, as described in
--   <a>RFC3492</a>. The sender name (also known as the <i>friendly
--   name</i>) may contain non-ASCII characters. These characters must be
--   encoded using MIME encoded-word syntax, as described in <a>RFC
--   2047</a>. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following form:
--   <tt>=?charset?encoding?encoded-text?=</tt>.
sendBulkTemplatedEmail_source :: Lens' SendBulkTemplatedEmail Text

-- | The template to use when sending this email.
sendBulkTemplatedEmail_template :: Lens' SendBulkTemplatedEmail Text

-- | One or more <tt>Destination</tt> objects. All of the recipients in a
--   <tt>Destination</tt> will receive the same version of the email. You
--   can specify up to 50 <tt>Destination</tt> objects within a
--   <tt>Destinations</tt> array.
sendBulkTemplatedEmail_destinations :: Lens' SendBulkTemplatedEmail [BulkEmailDestination]

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newSendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse</a> smart
--   constructor.
data SendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse
SendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse' :: Int -> [BulkEmailDestinationStatus] -> SendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:SendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse'] :: SendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse -> Int

-- | The unique message identifier returned from the
--   <tt>SendBulkTemplatedEmail</tt> action.
[$sel:status:SendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse'] :: SendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse -> [BulkEmailDestinationStatus]

-- | Create a value of <a>SendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:SendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse'</a>,
--   <a>sendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:SendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse'</a>,
--   <a>sendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse_status</a> - The unique message
--   identifier returned from the <tt>SendBulkTemplatedEmail</tt> action.
newSendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse :: Int -> SendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse

-- | The response's http status code.
sendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' SendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse Int

-- | The unique message identifier returned from the
--   <tt>SendBulkTemplatedEmail</tt> action.
sendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse_status :: Lens' SendBulkTemplatedEmailResponse [BulkEmailDestinationStatus]

-- | Generates and sends a bounce message to the sender of an email you
--   received through Amazon SES. You can only use this API on an email up
--   to 24 hours after you receive it.
--   
--   You cannot use this API to send generic bounces for mail that was not
--   received by Amazon SES.
--   
--   For information about receiving email through Amazon SES, see the
--   <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   You can execute this operation no more than once per second.
module Network.AWS.SES.SendBounce

-- | Represents a request to send a bounce message to the sender of an
--   email you received through Amazon SES.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSendBounce</a> smart constructor.
data SendBounce
SendBounce' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe MessageDsn -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> [BouncedRecipientInfo] -> SendBounce

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to use the address in the "From" header of the
--   bounce. For more information about sending authorization, see the
--   <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
[$sel:bounceSenderArn:SendBounce'] :: SendBounce -> Maybe Text

-- | Message-related DSN fields. If not specified, Amazon SES will choose
--   the values.
[$sel:messageDsn:SendBounce'] :: SendBounce -> Maybe MessageDsn

-- | Human-readable text for the bounce message to explain the failure. If
--   not specified, the text will be auto-generated based on the bounced
--   recipient information.
[$sel:explanation:SendBounce'] :: SendBounce -> Maybe Text

-- | The message ID of the message to be bounced.
[$sel:originalMessageId:SendBounce'] :: SendBounce -> Text

-- | The address to use in the "From" header of the bounce message. This
--   must be an identity that you have verified with Amazon SES.
[$sel:bounceSender:SendBounce'] :: SendBounce -> Text

-- | A list of recipients of the bounced message, including the information
--   required to create the Delivery Status Notifications (DSNs) for the
--   recipients. You must specify at least one
--   <tt>BouncedRecipientInfo</tt> in the list.
[$sel:bouncedRecipientInfoList:SendBounce'] :: SendBounce -> [BouncedRecipientInfo]

-- | Create a value of <a>SendBounce</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:bounceSenderArn:SendBounce'</a>,
--   <a>sendBounce_bounceSenderArn</a> - This parameter is used only for
--   sending authorization. It is the ARN of the identity that is
--   associated with the sending authorization policy that permits you to
--   use the address in the "From" header of the bounce. For more
--   information about sending authorization, see the <a>Amazon SES
--   Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:messageDsn:SendBounce'</a>, <a>sendBounce_messageDsn</a> -
--   Message-related DSN fields. If not specified, Amazon SES will choose
--   the values.
--   
--   <a>$sel:explanation:SendBounce'</a>, <a>sendBounce_explanation</a> -
--   Human-readable text for the bounce message to explain the failure. If
--   not specified, the text will be auto-generated based on the bounced
--   recipient information.
--   
--   <a>$sel:originalMessageId:SendBounce'</a>,
--   <a>sendBounce_originalMessageId</a> - The message ID of the message to
--   be bounced.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bounceSender:SendBounce'</a>, <a>sendBounce_bounceSender</a> -
--   The address to use in the "From" header of the bounce message. This
--   must be an identity that you have verified with Amazon SES.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bouncedRecipientInfoList:SendBounce'</a>,
--   <a>sendBounce_bouncedRecipientInfoList</a> - A list of recipients of
--   the bounced message, including the information required to create the
--   Delivery Status Notifications (DSNs) for the recipients. You must
--   specify at least one <tt>BouncedRecipientInfo</tt> in the list.
newSendBounce :: Text -> Text -> SendBounce

-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN
--   of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization
--   policy that permits you to use the address in the "From" header of the
--   bounce. For more information about sending authorization, see the
--   <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
sendBounce_bounceSenderArn :: Lens' SendBounce (Maybe Text)

-- | Message-related DSN fields. If not specified, Amazon SES will choose
--   the values.
sendBounce_messageDsn :: Lens' SendBounce (Maybe MessageDsn)

-- | Human-readable text for the bounce message to explain the failure. If
--   not specified, the text will be auto-generated based on the bounced
--   recipient information.
sendBounce_explanation :: Lens' SendBounce (Maybe Text)

-- | The message ID of the message to be bounced.
sendBounce_originalMessageId :: Lens' SendBounce Text

-- | The address to use in the "From" header of the bounce message. This
--   must be an identity that you have verified with Amazon SES.
sendBounce_bounceSender :: Lens' SendBounce Text

-- | A list of recipients of the bounced message, including the information
--   required to create the Delivery Status Notifications (DSNs) for the
--   recipients. You must specify at least one
--   <tt>BouncedRecipientInfo</tt> in the list.
sendBounce_bouncedRecipientInfoList :: Lens' SendBounce [BouncedRecipientInfo]

-- | Represents a unique message ID.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSendBounceResponse</a> smart constructor.
data SendBounceResponse
SendBounceResponse' :: Maybe Text -> Int -> SendBounceResponse

-- | The message ID of the bounce message.
[$sel:messageId:SendBounceResponse'] :: SendBounceResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:SendBounceResponse'] :: SendBounceResponse -> Int

sendBounceResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' SendBounceResponse Int

-- | Reorders the receipt rules within a receipt rule set.
--   
--   All of the rules in the rule set must be represented in this request.
--   That is, this API will return an error if the reorder request doesn't
--   explicitly position all of the rules.
--   
--   For information about managing receipt rule sets, see the <a>Amazon
--   SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   You can execute this operation no more than once per second.
module Network.AWS.SES.ReorderReceiptRuleSet

-- | Represents a request to reorder the receipt rules within a receipt
--   rule set. You use receipt rule sets to receive email with Amazon SES.
--   For more information, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newReorderReceiptRuleSet</a> smart constructor.
data ReorderReceiptRuleSet
ReorderReceiptRuleSet' :: Text -> [Text] -> ReorderReceiptRuleSet

-- | The name of the receipt rule set to reorder.
[$sel:ruleSetName:ReorderReceiptRuleSet'] :: ReorderReceiptRuleSet -> Text

-- | A list of the specified receipt rule set's receipt rules in the order
--   that you want to put them.
[$sel:ruleNames:ReorderReceiptRuleSet'] :: ReorderReceiptRuleSet -> [Text]

-- | Create a value of <a>ReorderReceiptRuleSet</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:ruleSetName:ReorderReceiptRuleSet'</a>,
--   <a>reorderReceiptRuleSet_ruleSetName</a> - The name of the receipt
--   rule set to reorder.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ruleNames:ReorderReceiptRuleSet'</a>,
--   <a>reorderReceiptRuleSet_ruleNames</a> - A list of the specified
--   receipt rule set's receipt rules in the order that you want to put
--   them.
newReorderReceiptRuleSet :: Text -> ReorderReceiptRuleSet

-- | The name of the receipt rule set to reorder.
reorderReceiptRuleSet_ruleSetName :: Lens' ReorderReceiptRuleSet Text

-- | A list of the specified receipt rule set's receipt rules in the order
--   that you want to put them.
reorderReceiptRuleSet_ruleNames :: Lens' ReorderReceiptRuleSet [Text]

-- | An empty element returned on a successful request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newReorderReceiptRuleSetResponse</a> smart constructor.

-- | Adds or updates a sending authorization policy for the specified
--   identity (an email address or a domain).
--   
--   This API is for the identity owner only. If you have not verified the
--   identity, this API will return an error.
--   
--   Sending authorization is a feature that enables an identity owner to
--   authorize other senders to use its identities. For information about
--   using sending authorization, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer
--   Guide</a>.
--   
--   You can execute this operation no more than once per second.
module Network.AWS.SES.PutIdentityPolicy

-- | Represents a request to add or update a sending authorization policy
--   for an identity. Sending authorization is an Amazon SES feature that
--   enables you to authorize other senders to use your identities. For
--   information, see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPutIdentityPolicy</a> smart constructor.
data PutIdentityPolicy
PutIdentityPolicy' :: Text -> Text -> Text -> PutIdentityPolicy

-- | The identity that the policy will apply to. You can specify an
--   identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN).
--   Examples: <tt>user@example.com</tt>, <tt>example.com</tt>,
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>.
--   
--   To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.
[$sel:identity:PutIdentityPolicy'] :: PutIdentityPolicy -> Text

-- | The name of the policy.
--   
--   The policy name cannot exceed 64 characters and can only include
--   alphanumeric characters, dashes, and underscores.
[$sel:policyName:PutIdentityPolicy'] :: PutIdentityPolicy -> Text

-- | The text of the policy in JSON format. The policy cannot exceed 4 KB.
--   
--   For information about the syntax of sending authorization policies,
--   see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
[$sel:policy:PutIdentityPolicy'] :: PutIdentityPolicy -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>PutIdentityPolicy</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--

--   <a>putIdentityPolicy_identity</a> - The identity that the policy will
--   apply to. You can specify an identity by using its name or by using
--   its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: <tt>user@example.com</tt>,
--   <tt>example.com</tt>,
--   <tt>arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com</tt>.
--   
--   To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyName:PutIdentityPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>putIdentityPolicy_policyName</a> - The name of the policy.
--   
--   The policy name cannot exceed 64 characters and can only include
--   alphanumeric characters, dashes, and underscores.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policy:PutIdentityPolicy'</a>, <a>putIdentityPolicy_policy</a>
--   - The text of the policy in JSON format. The policy cannot exceed 4
--   KB.
--   
--   For information about the syntax of sending authorization policies,
--   see the <a>Amazon SES Developer Guide</a>.
newPutIdentityPolicy :: Text -> Text -> Text -> PutIdentityPolicy

--   identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN).
--   Examples: <tt>user@example.com</tt>, <tt>example.com</tt>,

--   
--   To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

--   alphanumeric characters, dashes, and underscores.
